pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 133, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 118, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 369, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 579, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 461]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 461, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 476, 364, 491]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 492, 329, 506]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 680, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 560, 615]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 774, 195]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 767, 91]]<|/det|> The mass of air hitting the blades of a wind turbine each second is \(1.5 \times 10^{4} \text{kg}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 376, 121]]<|/det|> The speed of the air is \(4.0 \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 371, 152]]<|/det|> The density of air is \(1.2 \text{kg/m}^3\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 160, 562, 312]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 922, 356]]<|/det|> Which row gives the volume of the air hitting the blades each second and the kinetic energy of the air hitting the blades each second? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 367, 529, 513]]<|/det|>
volume of air
each second/m³		kinetic energy
each second/J
A13 00072 000

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 540, 97, 558]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 497, 558]]<|/det|> An object moves in a circle at constant speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 570, 655, 588]]<|/det|> Which statement about the force needed on the object is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 599, 133, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 801, 616]]<|/det|> A force away from the centre of the circle keeps the object moving in the circle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 133, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 625, 764, 644]]<|/det|> A force in the direction of motion of the object keeps it moving in the circle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 652, 133, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 652, 781, 670]]<|/det|> A force towards the centre of the circle keeps the object moving in the circle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 678, 133, 696]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 678, 781, 696]]<|/det|> No force is needed to keep the object moving at constant speed in the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 922, 107]]<|/det|> A mass bounces up and down on a steel spring. The diagram shows the mass and the spring at different points during the motion. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 112, 803, 325]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 920, 373]]<|/det|> At which point is the least energy in the gravitational potential store of the mass and at which point is the most energy in the elastic store of the spring? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 594, 545]]<|/det|>
least energy in gravitational potential store of the massmost energy in the elastic store of the spring
Amass moving downmass moving up
Bmass moving downlowest point
Clowest pointmass moving up
Dlowest pointlowest point
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 572, 96, 590]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 571, 589, 591]]<|/det|> A boy uses a rope to pull an object of mass \(m\) up a slope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 384, 621]]<|/det|> The rope is parallel to the slope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 632, 531, 651]]<|/det|> The tension in the rope is constant and of value \(F\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 742, 681]]<|/det|> The object moves a distance \(d\) along the slope and rises through a height \(h\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 692, 418, 710]]<|/det|> How much work is done by the boy? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 721, 139, 739]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 721, 200, 739]]<|/det|> \(F\times d\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 139, 767]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 750, 198, 767]]<|/det|> \(F\times h\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 134, 795]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 777, 266, 795]]<|/det|> \(m\times g\times h\times d\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 136, 822]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 804, 240, 822]]<|/det|> \(m\times g\times h^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 447, 88]]<|/det|> A microwave oven is rated at 900 watts. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 640, 120]]<|/det|> Which statement correctly describes the meaning of this value? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 487, 147]]<|/det|> 900 joules are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 131, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 510, 174]]<|/det|> 900 amperes are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 477, 201]]<|/det|> 900 volts are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 485, 225]]<|/det|> 900 ohms are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 255, 107, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 920, 288]]<|/det|> An object is immersed in a liquid of density \(\rho\). The pressure at this depth due to the liquid is \(p\). The gravitational field strength is \(g\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 299, 700, 317]]<|/det|> What is the equation for the depth \(h\) of the object beneath the surface? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 133, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 330, 222, 348]]<|/det|> \(h = \rho \rho g\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 327, 298, 346]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 325, 381, 356]]<|/det|> \(h = \frac{\rho g}{\rho}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 327, 480, 346]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 325, 551, 356]]<|/det|> \(h = \frac{p}{\rho g}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 327, 635, 346]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 327, 717, 356]]<|/det|> $h = \frac{\rho g}{\rho}$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 387, 107, 405]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 510, 405]]<|/det|> A sealed bottle of constant volume contains air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 418, 460, 437]]<|/det|> The air in the bottle is heated by the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|> What is the effect on the average speed of the air particles in the bottle and the average distance between them? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 500, 655]]<|/det|>
average speed of air particlesaverage distance between air particles
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesstays the same
Cincreasesincreases
Dincreasesstays the same

12

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 628, 109, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 626, 818, 645]]<|/det|> A student splashes water on to her face. Here are three statements about the effects. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 657, 529, 675]]<|/det|> P The water uses energy to evaporate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 683, 564, 701]]<|/det|> Q The water gains energy from the student. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 710, 470, 728]]<|/det|> R The face of the student cools. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 371, 757]]<|/det|> Which statements are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 767, 134, 785]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 767, 751, 785]]<|/det|> P and Q only B P and R only C Q and R only D P, Q and R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 567, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the effect of a prism on white light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Some light is reflected on striking the prism and some is refracted and dispersed to form a spectrum.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 144, 690, 299]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 672, 329]]<|/det|>
What happens if monochromatic light is used instead of white light?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 134, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 338, 615, 357]]<|/det|>
The light changes colour as it passes through the prism.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 364, 133, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 364, 447, 383]]<|/det|>

<label>C</label>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 416, 517, 435]]<|/det|>

<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 606, 479]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a ray of light incident on a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 517, 628]]<|/det|>
The angle between the ray and the mirror is \(35^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 391, 657]]<|/det|>
The ray is reflected by the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 669, 374, 687]]<|/det|>
What is the angle of reflection?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 133, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 698, 185, 717]]<|/det|>
35°

The only wire available has twice the diameter of the broken wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 686, 463, 704]]<|/det|> Which length of this wire should be used? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 718, 134, 737]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 718, 173, 737]]<|/det|> \(\frac {L}{4}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 718, 298, 737]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[318, 718, 341, 737]]<|/det|> \(\frac {L}{2}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 720, 468, 739]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 720, 510, 739]]<|/det|> 2L <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 720, 635, 739]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 720, 678, 739]]<|/det|> 4L

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 653, 90]]<|/det|>
A teacher wishes to show the production of electrostatic charges.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
She holds a rod and rubs it with a cotton cloth. A copper rod, a glass rod, a plastic rod and a steel rod are available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 504, 165]]<|/det|>
Which two rods would both be suitable to use?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 136, 194]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 175, 390, 193]]<|/det|>
a copper rod and a glass rod

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 202, 134, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 202, 390, 220]]<|/det|>
a glass rod and a plastic rod

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 134, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 228, 400, 246]]<|/det|>
a plastic rod and a copper rod

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 133, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 254, 384, 272]]<|/det|>
a plastic rod and a steel rod

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 298, 106, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 720, 316]]<|/det|>
Two resistors, with resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\), are used as a potential divider.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 323, 583, 492]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 503, 745, 522]]<|/det|>
What is the relationship between \(R_{1}, R_{2}\) and potential differences \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 533, 134, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 533, 297, 551]]<|/det|>
\(R_{1}\times R_{2} = V_{1}\times V_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 131, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 560, 297, 579]]<|/det|>
\(R_{1}\times V_{1} = R_{2}\times V_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 131, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 588, 265, 616]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}} = V_{1}\times V_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 635, 133, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 631, 230, 660]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}} = \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\)

resistance of LDRreading on voltmeter

Dincreasesincreases

peak e.m.f.frequency

increasing the current

The scattering of \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) by a thin gold foil provides evidence for the nuclear model of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 445, 606]]<|/det|>
The half-life of carbon-14 is 5700 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 618, 920, 651]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 663, 892, 682]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 114, 133, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 114, 574, 133]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 141, 465, 160]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 166, 133, 185]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 166, 616, 185]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 193, 655, 211]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 237, 106, 255]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 913, 255]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 265, 480, 284]]<|/det|>
Atoms join together to make molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 292, 133, 310]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 292, 448, 310]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 318, 133, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 318, 544, 337]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 344, 133, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 344, 435, 363]]<|/det|>
Molecules break down into atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 389, 106, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 388, 811, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 592, 717, 611]]<|/det|>
The time for one orbit of Y is three times the time taken for one orbit of X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 622, 668, 640]]<|/det|>
The time for one orbit of Z is twice the time taken for one orbit of Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 920, 686]]<|/det|>
Starting from the initial arrangement, which diagram shows the positions of the planets after X has made one complete orbit?

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 725, 260, 841]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 698, 403, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 725, 479, 841]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[598, 698, 618, 715]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 725, 695, 841]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[816, 698, 836, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 725, 908, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 717, 91]]<|/det|>
The nearest star to the Sun is about four light-years away from the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 526, 120]]<|/det|>
A student makes three statements about the star.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 131, 720, 150]]<|/det|>
1 Light from the star takes about four years to reach the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 158, 912, 177]]<|/det|>
2 Light from the Sun takes about four years to travel to the star and back to the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 184, 475, 203]]<|/det|>
3 The star is outside our galaxy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 214, 371, 231]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 241, 134, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 188, 260]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 241, 237, 260]]<|/det|>
2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 241, 300, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 241, 425, 260]]<|/det|>
1 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 241, 470, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 241, 541, 260]]<|/det|>
1 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 241, 636, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 241, 761, 260]]<|/det|>
2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 286, 106, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 774, 304]]<|/det|>
A planet orbits the Sun with orbital period \(T\). The average radius of the orbit is \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 515, 336]]<|/det|>
What is the average orbital speed of the planet?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 133, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 348, 168, 366]]<|/det|>
2\(\pi r T\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 346, 300, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 344, 359, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{2\pi r}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 346, 470, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 344, 525, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{T}{2\pi r}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 348, 635, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[653, 344, 688, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\pi r}{2T}\]
